channel.title: Comments on: How to identify Feature Envy using NDepend

item.title: By: How to identify efferent coupling code smells using NDepend - Simple Oriented Architecture

item.title: By: How to identify a Data Class using NDepend - Simple Oriented Architecture

item.title: By: Victor
item.dc:creator: Victor
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-identify-feature-envy-using-ndepend/#comment-31">PatrickSmacchia</a>.
Thanks!
I did have a (shallow) look at the NDepend Power Tools and they look great. By using the NDepend API, we can remove the code duplication and probably compute all metrics only once. But I would prefer something that's integrated in Visual Studio (like the queries and rules editor).
item.content:encoded:
In reply to PatrickSmacchia.

Thanks!

I did have a (shallow) look at the NDepend Power Tools and they look great. By using the NDepend API, we can remove the code duplication and probably compute all metrics only once. But I would prefer something that’s integrated in Visual Studio (like the queries and rules editor).

item.title: By: PatrickSmacchia
item.dc:creator: PatrickSmacchia
item.description:
Awesome work!!
> The only thing that is bothering me is code duplication
Have you look at the OSS NDepend Power Tool relative to code cloning by analyzing who is using what?
item.content:encoded:
Awesome work!!

> The only thing that is bothering me is code duplication

Have you look at the OSS NDepend Power Tool relative to code cloning by analyzing who is using what?
